experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest, I’m a little stressed—I have a huge presentation coming up for my algorithms class and the thought of speaking in a 200-person lecture hall is kind of freaking me out.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel that way—even with low social anxiety, big presentations can be nerve-wracking. Try practicing in front of a smaller group first, like friends or a study group. Focus on your passion for the topic; it'll make you more engaging. You've got the skills and energy to rock this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess I could try that with my study group... It's just hard to focus on the passion part when I'm so worried about my grade.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid concern—grades matter, but remember, your professor wants you to succeed too! Try breaking your presentation into smaller sections and mastering one at a time. Visualize yourself doing well; it can ease anxiety. You're clearly dedicated—that's half the battle won already.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try breaking it down... but visualizing success feels a little naive when my code still has bugs. I just really need an 'A' on this to keep my grad school hopes alive.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's not naive—visualization is a tool many successful people use! But I hear you: focus on what you can control. Debug systematically, and maybe visit office hours for feedback. One presentation won't make or break grad school—they look at your whole story. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I can try the systematic approach... but my whole story feels like it's mostly bug reports right now.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, every programmer's story is full of bug reports—that's how we learn! Those struggles show persistence, which grad schools value. Celebrate small wins: each bug fixed is proof you're growing. Keep a "wins list" to remind yourself how far you've come. You're building resilience, not just code.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to see it as a win when I'm staring at a broken function for three hours straight. Maybe I'll try writing one down next time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Even noting "spent 3 hours debugging—learned X doesn't work with Y" turns frustration into a learning milestone. Progress isn't always a green checkmark; sometimes it's ruling out what *doesn't* work. Keep that list going—it'll add up faster than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It just feels like I'm collecting a list of failures instead of actual progress sometimes.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it like this: every "failure" you document is actually data that narrows down the path to success. Even failed experiments are valuable—they're eliminating options. Your list isn't failures; it's a map of what you've ruled out. That's real progress in disguise.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Huh, I guess I never thought of it like collecting data before. It just feels like I'm making a list of all the ways I've messed up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Scientists don't call experiments "failures"—they're results that inform the next hypothesis. Your debugging list is the same: each entry gets you closer to the solution. Reframe it as research, not mistakes. You're building knowledge, not just fixing code.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Huh, I never thought of it like that. I guess my debug log is just... data. Still feels pretty lousy when the data says my code is broken, though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—the frustration is real! But remember: broken code is just a puzzle, not a reflection on you. Every bug you solve makes you a stronger programmer. Celebrate fixing each one; that's where the real growth happens. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it's hard not to feel like every bug is a personal failure when my GPA is on the line. I just wish it felt more like a puzzle and less like a test I'm constantly failing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That pressure is real, especially at a competitive school. But try this: separate your self-worth from your code's bugs. Even senior engineers at top companies debug daily—it's part of the craft, not a measure of intelligence. Your GPA reflects persistence, not perfection. Keep iterating!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard not to feel like every failed compile is a personal failure when grad school applications are looming.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's completely normal to feel that pressure, especially with grad school goals. But admissions committees look for resilience and problem-solving skills—which you're building every time you debug! Think of each compile error as proof you're pushing your limits. That persistence is exactly what they value.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's one way to look at it... I just wish I felt as confident debugging my grad school applications as I do my code.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great point—and you can apply the same debugging mindset! Break your application into smaller parts (personal statement, resume, recommendations) and "test" each one. Get feedback like you would on code, iterate, and refine. You're already skilled at problem-solving—just redirect that talent!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a really good way to look at it. I guess I just get overwhelmed seeing it as one big, monolithic application.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Breaking it down makes it manageable. Tackle one section at a time—like fixing one bug before moving to the next. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, that's... a good way to look at it. I just hope the whole paper doesn't feel like one big, unfixable bug.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it like refactoring code—you don’t rewrite the whole program at once. Small, consistent edits add up to a polished final product. You’ve already built strong skills; trust the process.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good analogy, actually. I guess I just get overwhelmed thinking about the final product—like my grad school applications. It feels like one wrong variable and the whole thing crashes.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: But remember—applications aren’t code. They’re reviewed by humans who expect growth, not perfection. One “bug” won’t crash your chances. Focus on telling your unique story, not eliminating every flaw.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it's hard not to obsess over every single line when I know how competitive grad school is. I just don't want my story to sound like everyone else's.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's exactly your edge—your unique perspective. Lean into what makes your journey different, even the challenges. Authenticity stands out more than polished perfection in a sea of similar applications.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe my messy journey is an advantage when everyone else seems so put together.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Nobody has it all figured out—they’re just better at hiding the messy parts. Your realness is relatable and memorable. Grad schools want passionate people, not perfect robots.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's true... it's just hard not to compare my behind-the-scenes to everyone else's highlight reel. I really hope the admissions committee sees it that way.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Focus on showing your growth and curiosity—that’s what makes a standout applicant. You’ve got this, Gregory.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I'll try to highlight that in my statement, but I'm still worried my grades aren't competitive enough for the programs I want.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Strong letters of recommendation and a compelling personal statement can balance solid-but-not-perfect grades. Emphasize your projects and what you’ve learned, not just the GPA.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a huge relief to hear. I always get so stressed that my 3.4 GPA will just get my application tossed immediately.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: A 3.4 from a rigorous CS program is solid! Many programs look holistically. Focus on showcasing your unique strengths and passion—you’re more than a number.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, it's just hard not to fixate on the number when grad school feels so competitive. I guess I need to figure out what my "unique strengths" even are.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start by listing projects you're proud of and skills you've gained outside class. Your passion and initiative often stand out more than a perfect GPA.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could talk about that machine learning project I did for the hackathon... but I'm not sure if it's impressive enough for grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a perfect start! Grad schools love seeing initiative. Frame it to show your problem-solving process and what you learned, not just the final result. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, but what if they think my problem-solving process was actually kind of messy? I'm worried it'll just highlight my mistakes instead of the final outcome.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Messing up is part of learning! Frame it as growth—explain how you adapted when things didn’t go as planned. That shows resilience, which admissions committees value.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could talk about that time my code failed spectacularly during a hackathon... but I still figured out a better solution by the end.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! That’s a powerful story. Showing how you handled failure and pivoted demonstrates maturity and problem-solving skills—traits every grad program looks for.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard to believe a story about messing up a project is actually a good thing to talk about.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it this way: a perfect story is forgettable. A story about overcoming a messy challenge is memorable and shows real character. You're not just a student; you're a resilient problem-solver. Own it

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to see my own messes as anything but failures sometimes. But you're right, graduate schools probably do want to see that I can actually solve problems.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Grad schools want people who can navigate real-world challenges, not just ace exams. Your hackathon story proves you're adaptable—that's a huge strength. Keep leaning into that mindset.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard to believe it counts as much as a perfect GPA when I'm looking at graduate program requirements.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: A perfect GPA shows you can learn; your story shows you can *apply* that learning when things go wrong. Both matter, but the latter is what makes you stand out in a pool of high achievers. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe a story about me stressing over a coding project would ever matter more than a 4.0.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it this way: a 4.0 is a prerequisite. Your story is the essay that convinces them you're the *right* person for their program. It's the human element that makes you unforgettable.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I just worry my story isn't as compelling as someone who's had more... obvious challenges.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Your challenge was overcoming pressure in a high-stakes environment—that's incredibly compelling! It's not about the scale of the problem, but how you grew from it. Own your journey.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess... it just feels like my journey is mostly about avoiding things that stress me out, not really overcoming them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Recognizing what stresses you out is the first step to managing it—that's a form of overcoming! Maybe start small: speak up once in a smaller class. Each time you do, you're rewriting that story from avoidance to engagement.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that in my algorithms seminar—it's only about fifteen people. It's just hard to shake the feeling that I'll say something stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! And remember, in a seminar, asking a clarifying question is often helpful to others too. It shows you're engaged. Even if it feels awkward, it's a sign of strength, not stupidity. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard to remember that in the moment when I'm worried my question might sound dumb.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that. Try writing down one question before class—then you already have a "script." Takes the pressure off deciding in the moment. Small prep can build big confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually not a bad idea. I could probably manage one pre-written question, especially for my Algorithms class where I'm terrified of sounding stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Start with something simple like "Could you clarify that last step?" It's a low-risk way to build momentum. You're already on the right track by planning ahead—keep it up!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds manageable. I'll try that in my study group tomorrow, but I'm still worried about sounding unsure during my presentation next week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: For the presentation, practice your opening line until it's automatic. A strong start builds momentum and calms nerves. You know your material—trust that.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my mind just goes blank the second I see everyone looking at me. What if I freeze up anyway, even with a perfect opening?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s totally normal! Try putting a small sticky note on your laptop with a keyword or two—just a safety net. If you freeze, pause, take a breath, glance at the note. It’s okay to slow down; you’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That... actually seems too simple to work. But I guess I could try it for my Data Structures presentation next week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sometimes the simplest solutions are the most effective! The sticky note trick works because it gives you a visual anchor to regain focus. You've prepared well—trust your knowledge and this small backup plan. Good luck with your presentation!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll try the sticky notes. I'm just worried my mind will go blank anyway, even with the prompts.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid fear, but remember: the sticky note isn't just for content—it's a reminder to breathe and pause. Even experienced speakers have moments of silence. A brief pause feels longer to you than to your audience. You can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I know you're right about the pause thing. It just feels like everyone can see me scrambling for a second up there.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—and most people in the audience are just relieved it's not them up there! They're not judging you as harshly as you think. A quick pause to gather your thoughts actually makes you look more composed. You've got the skills and the prep—now trust yourself.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a really good point. I guess I never thought about it that way. It's just hard to remember in the moment when my mind goes blank.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal! Try practicing your opening line until it's automatic—that way, even if you blank later, you can start strong. The first 30 seconds are the hardest; after that, momentum usually takes over. You've got this, Gregory.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess I could try that. It's just hard to imagine the momentum kicking in when my mind goes completely blank the second I have to present.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "blank" feeling is just adrenaline. Channel it as excitement, not fear. Practice your first line so much it's like saying your name—it'll anchor you. Once you get past that, the rest flows easier. You're more prepared than you feel.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that... but my mind still goes completely blank when I see everyone looking at me. What if I practice it and still freeze up?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: If you freeze, pause, take a breath, and glance at your notes—it feels like forever to you, but it’s only a second to the audience. Even experienced speakers do this! The goal isn’t perfection; it’s getting your message across. You’re capable of recovering, I promise.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but in that moment, my brain just screams that everyone can see I'm failing. I'll try to remember it's about the message, not being perfect.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I’m honestly a little nervous, but I really want to work on being better at… well, talking to people, especially if I need to find a job soon.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel nervous—many students do. Start small: practice introducing yourself to one new person in a virtual class or club this week. Remember, networking is a skill that improves with practice, and you're already taking a great first step by reaching out. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try that with someone in the Computer Science club forum. I'm just worried I won't know what to say after "hello."

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart plan! Try asking open-ended questions like "What projects are you working on?" or "How did you get interested in CS?" People love talking about their passions, and it takes pressure off you to carry the conversation. You're thoughtful—use that to your advantage by listening actively.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Hey Gregory, thanks for being open about that. I felt the same way about "soft skills" until I realized engineering is all about teamwork and communication. For research positions specifically, professors often choose students who can clearly explain their work and collaborate well.

Want to try a low-pressure step? Next time you're in office hours, ask one thoughtful question about their research. It's a natural way to build connections without feeling like "networking." Small steps count!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but what if my question is stupid? I don't want a professor to remember me as the guy who asked something obvious.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that fear - but professors actually love curious students! Try framing it as "I was thinking about X in your research - could you help me understand Y aspect?" This shows engagement rather than ignorance. Most undergrad questions aren't groundbreaking, and that's expected!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if Y aspect is something I should already know? I don't want to look stupid before I even ask for a research position.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Here's a secret: professors expect undergrads to have knowledge gaps - that's why they're teachers! Phrasing like "I'm trying to deepen my understanding of..." makes it clear you're being thoughtful, not unprepared. Your engineering classes give you the foundation; research is about building beyond that.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but when I ask a question and get that blank stare, it just confirms I'm behind everyone else. "Deepening my understanding" feels like a fancy way of saying I didn't do the reading.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "blank stare" is usually them thinking - not judging! Try "Based on my current understanding from [specific class/topic], I'm wondering how Z connects?" This shows you've done the groundwork. Everyone feels behind sometimes - the fact you're even asking proves you're ahead of most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Maybe, but it still feels like they're waiting for me to say something stupid. I just freeze up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Write down 2-3 bullet points before meeting them - it's your safety net. When you freeze, glance at your notes. Even saying "Let me gather my thoughts" is professional. You're not alone in this - many successful engineers felt exactly the same way starting out.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Bullet points? I freeze so hard I can't even see the paper. What if I just blank and look like an idiot in front of everyone?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try this: email your questions beforehand. Then open with "Following up on my email about X..." - now you've got a script. Professors LOVE when students do this prep work. It turns pressure into a structured conversation. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually not a bad idea. At least then I won't just stand there blankly when they ask what I want.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! You're turning anxiety into preparation. Bonus: professors often prepare answers in advance when they see your email. You're not just helping yourself - you're making their job easier too. Win-win.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but what if my question is the one they *didn't* prepare for? Then I'm just putting them on the spot, which is worse.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Actually, that's when you shine! Say "I'd love to hear your initial thoughts" - it shows you value their perspective. Most professors enjoy thoughtful questions that make them pause. You're not being difficult; you're being engaging.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if they *don't* have any initial thoughts and they just think I'm wasting their time?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Here's the secret: professors respect intellectual curiosity. If they don't have an immediate answer, they'll often say "Let me think about that" - which means you've sparked genuine interest. That's how research collaborations begin. You're not wasting time; you're showing potential.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if I ask something stupid and they just say that to be polite? I'm not trying to waste anyone's time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Gregory, I've been there! Professors hear truly basic questions daily - yours won't be the "stupid" one. Their polite deflection usually means they want to give your question proper consideration. That's a good sign! Research is about exploring unknowns together. You're bringing value by showing genuine interest.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if my genuine interest is just... obvious? I don't want to be the one exploring an unknown that everyone else already knows the answer to.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's exactly what makes a great researcher! "Obvious" questions often uncover overlooked assumptions. Many breakthroughs start with someone brave enough to ask "Why is it done this way?" Your perspective as a student is valuable precisely because you see things differently. You're not repeating what's known - you're building on it.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but knowing that doesn't make it any easier to actually speak up in a room full of professors. I just freeze.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small! Email one professor after class with a specific question about their research. This builds confidence without the pressure of speaking in front of a group. turns.speaker: ai

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if I freeze up while I'm reading it? My mind just goes completely blank the second I have to talk to someone important.

turns.speaker: ai

Even if you freeze, taking a breath and saying "Let me gather my thoughts" shows self-awareness, not incompetence. Everyone struggles with this; what matters is that you're trying.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Actually, recruiters respect candidates who handle pressure calmly! Pausing to collect yourself shows maturity, not failure. It's far better than rambling. turns.speaker: ai

responses.question: I ask for help when I need it.

responses.question: I stay calm when dealing with problems.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 2. [Rating: 1/4] I really don't stay calm. My mind immediately jumps to the worst-case scenario, especially with engineering problems. I get overwhelmed and usually have to step away for a bit....

responses.question: I help my friends when they are having a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 3. [Rating: 4/4] If a friend is having a problem, I'm definitely there for them. It's easier to focus on someone else's issues than my own, and I genuinely want to help....

responses.question: I work well with my classmates.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 4. [Rating: 3/4] I do work well with classmates, but mostly one-on-one or in very small groups. In larger teams, I get quiet and let others take the lead because I'm worried about saying something stu...

responses.question: I do the right thing without being told.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 5. [Rating: 4/4] Yeah, I'm pretty responsible about this. I hate the feeling of knowing I should do something and not doing it. It adds to my anxiety....

responses.question: I do my part in a group.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 6. [Rating: 4/4] I always make sure my part is done and done well. The fear of letting the group down is a huge motivator, even with my procrastination issues....

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 7. [Rating: 1/4] I hate disagreement. My heart starts pounding and I usually just go quiet or agree to avoid any more conflict. It's not productive, but it feels safer....

responses.question: I stand up for others when they are not treated well.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 8. [Rating: 2/4] I want to stand up for others, I really do. But my social anxiety kicks in hard. I'll probably feel awful about it later and wish I had said something....

responses.question: I look at people when I talk to them.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 9. [Rating: 2/4] I try, but maintaining eye contact is really difficult. I often find myself looking at my hands or just past their shoulder to avoid the intensity of it....

responses.question: I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 10. [Rating: 4/4] I'm overly careful. I'm always stressed about not having enough money to replace something if I broke it, so I treat other people's stuff better than my own....

responses.notes: Self-assessment: 11. [Rating: 2/4] This depends. If it's a technical problem, maybe. If it's a social problem or a group dynamic issue, I'll probably just keep it to myself to avoid the confrontation....

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Hey Lisa! Totally get it—presentations can be nerve-wracking, especially when you're dealing with social anxiety. It's awesome that you're taking this step, even if it feels forced right now.

A quick tip: practice your presentation out loud, even just to yourself or a trusted friend. Start small and focus on your breathing to stay calm. You've got great ideas—let them shine! What's one thing you enjoy about your Communications major that you could bring into your next presentation?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Practicing out loud just makes me more aware of how stupid I sound. The only thing I enjoy is writing the script, but then I have to ruin it by actually presenting it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
I totally get that—hearing your own voice can feel awkward! But remember: your script is strong because you wrote it, and that's half the battle. 

Try recording yourself instead of live practice. You can review it privately and notice what actually works (vs. what just *feels* awkward). Most people sound more capable than they think! 

What if you focused on sharing your well-written ideas rather than "performing"? You're not ruining anything—you're giving your words a voice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine, but the script is the only part that doesn't feel like a disaster. I just don't want my voice to ruin all that work.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That makes sense—you've put so much care into your script, and it's natural to worry about the delivery. But your voice isn't ruining your work; it's sharing it! Think of it as letting your great writing breathe and connect with others.

Maybe try practicing with a focus on one strength at a time—like clarity or pacing—instead of judging your voice overall. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess, but it's not just my voice—what if my points aren't strong enough and they just think my whole project is stupid?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That's a totally valid fear, but remember: you're your own toughest critic. If your script feels strong to you, chances are your points are clearer and more impactful than you think. 

Try this: share your key points with a classmate or professor you trust for feedback before presenting. Their perspective can reassure you and help refine your ideas. You're not alone in this—everyone worries about their work being judged. Your effort already shows how much you care, and that counts for a lot!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could ask someone, but honestly, what if their feedback just confirms it's a mess? I just need to get it over with.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
It's totally normal to fear negative feedback, but remember—asking for input isn't about proving it's a mess. It's about making something good even stronger. Even if they suggest changes, that doesn't mean your work is bad—it means you're growing!

And if you're feeling overwhelmed, just focus on getting through the presentation step by step. You've prepared, and that's already a huge win. Trust your effort—you can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it still feels like I'm handing them a reason to confirm I'm not cut out for this major. I just need to get through the ten minutes without my voice shaking.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
I totally get that—ten minutes can feel like forever when you're nervous. But remember: shaky voice or not, you belong in your major. Everyone gets nervous, and your passion for the subject shows through even when you're anxious.

Try practicing while breathing deeply, or focus on one friendly face in the audience. You're not proving yourself in ten minutes—you're sharing what you already know. You've got this, and I'm cheering for you!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say. My voice doesn't just get shaky, my whole brain freezes and I forget everything I know.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That's a scary feeling, and you're not alone—brain freezes happen to the best of us! Try this practical trick: create a small notecard with just 3-5 key bullet points (not full sentences). If you freeze, glance down—it’ll jog your memory without breaking your flow.

Also, practice presenting to your phone camera. It’s low-pressure, and you’ll see you know more than you think. The goal isn’t perfection; it’s getting your ideas across. You’re capable, even when anxiety tries to convince you otherwise.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, but what if I glance down and then can't look back up? And filming myself sounds like a special kind of torture.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Fair point—filming can feel awkward! But you don’t have to watch it right away; just recording helps you practice speaking out loud. And if glancing down worries you, try placing your notes near the back of the room. That way, looking up becomes natural again.

Start small: present to a mirror or a trusted friend first. The goal is building comfort, not perfection. You're stronger than your anxiety thinks you are—one step at a time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, even the thought of setting up a camera makes my skin crawl. And a mirror? That's just staring at the problem.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
You're right—forcing yourself into uncomfortable methods can backfire. What if you tried audio recording instead? Just voice, no video. Listen back while doing something calming, like doodling or walking. It removes the pressure of being watched while still helping you rehearse.

Small steps count. Even talking through your presentation while cooking or showering builds muscle memory. You don’t have to face the hardest part first.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that, but honestly, even hearing my own voice makes me cringe. What if I just sound like an idiot?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Totally get that—most people hate hearing their own voice! It sounds different to you than to others. Remember, your audience hears your passion and knowledge, not the tiny quirks you fixate on.

Try this: record just 30 seconds. Listen once, then delete it. No judgment, just exposure. It gets easier each time. You're not an idiot; you're just unfamiliar with your own sound. Be kind to yourself—progress over perfection.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That’s a solid start—setting boundaries like “once and delete” is smart. It’s about taking control, not punishing yourself. Even that quick listen builds familiarity and reduces the cringe factor over time.

Proud of you for taking this step! Remember, it’s not about being perfect—it’s about making progress. You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, well, it still feels stupid. But I guess if I don't start somewhere, I'll never get that research position.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Exactly! That research position is a great motivator. Think of this as training for the real thing—every pro was once a beginner who felt awkward too. 

You're not just recording your voice; you're building confidence for opportunities you deserve. Keep your goal in sight, and remember: courage is doing it scared. You're already ahead by trying.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but it's easy for you to say. I still feel like an idiot talking to my phone, and the idea of actually doing this in front of a professor makes me want to hide.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
You're right—it's not easy, and feeling awkward is totally normal! Even professors had to start somewhere. The phone practice is your safe space to stumble so the real thing feels less intimidating.

Think of it like a rehearsal: the more you practice in private, the more natural it'll feel when it counts. You're building resilience, not just recording clips. Keep going—you're stronger than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
I totally get that—the fear of judgment is real. But reframe it: you're not practicing to fail; you're practicing to *succeed*. Every recording is a chance to spot what works and build on it. 

Professors respect students who prepare, even if they're a bit nervous. Your effort shows dedication, not failure. Keep going—you're building skills, not just facing fears.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it just feels like every time I hit record, all I see is everything I'm doing wrong. It's hard to believe a professor would see that as dedication and not just incompetence.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That self-criticism is a sign you care deeply—which is exactly what professors value! They know growth comes from trying, not from being perfect right away. 

Try this: after each recording, name one thing you did *well*, even if it's small. You're training your brain to notice progress, not just flaws. You've got this.

turns.message: Progress isn't about perfection—it's about momentum. Just one "good thing" noticed today makes it easier to spot two tomorrow. turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That dread is totally normal—it means this presentation matters to you. But remember: you're not aiming to be flawless, just to share what you've learned. 

Focus on connecting with one person in the audience instead of worrying about everyone. You've prepared, and that already puts you ahead. Deep breath—you can do this.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear! Have a backup plan: put a few bullet points on a notecard just for reassurance. If your mind goes blank, pause, take a breath, and glance at your notes—it looks thoughtful, not panicked. Practice saying, "Let me gather my thoughts for a moment." Audiences are more supportive than you think. You've got solid content; trust your preparation.

turns.message: A notecard? I've tried that. My mind goes completely blank anyway and then I'm just staring at a piece of paper. People can definitely tell it's panic.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try this: instead of full sentences, use single keywords or simple icons on your card—just visual triggers. Also, practice presenting to a wall or recording yourself; it builds muscle memory so your mouth can keep going even if your brain hesitates. And remember: brief pauses feel much longer to you than to your audience. You're more capable than your anxiety tells you.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Keywords? Seriously? My brain blanks out enough without making my note cards even more useless. And talking to a wall just feels stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Fair point—let's try something different. Record a short voice memo of your main points and listen to it right before you present. That way it's fresh in your mind. turns.message: Fine, but it has to be Sam. And if I record it, I'm just going to obsess over how my voice sounds.

Before presentations, practice with a friend or record yourself to build confidence. Remember, many students feel the same way, so you're not alone. Take it one step at a time—you've got this!

responses.notes: Self-assessment: 2. [Rating: 1/4] I wish I could say I stay calm, but I really don't. My mind immediately jumps to the worst-case scenario, especially with math problems. I get overwhelmed and anxious very easily....

responses.question: I help my friends when they are having a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 3. [Rating: 4/4] If a friend has a problem, I'm always there to listen. It feels easier to focus on someone else's issues than my own, and I genuinely want to help them feel better....

responses.question: I work well with my classmates.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 4. [Rating: 2/4] I get very quiet in group settings. I prefer to just do my assigned part independently. The idea of having to speak up and collaborate in real-time makes me incredibly anxious....

responses.question: I do the right thing without being told.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 5. [Rating: 4/4] I'm very conscientious about rules and doing what's expected. I'd feel too guilty if I didn't, and following procedures helps reduce my anxiety....

responses.question: I do my part in a group.

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.

responses.question: I stand up for others when they are not treated well.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 8. [Rating: 3/4] I feel strongly about this and want to stand up for others, but my social anxiety sometimes holds me back from speaking up in the moment. I usually end up supporting the person privat...

responses.question: I look at people when I talk to them.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 9. [Rating: 2/4] I try, but maintaining eye contact is really difficult for me. I often find myself looking at my hands or the floor because direct eye contact feels too intense and personal....

responses.question: I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 10. [Rating: 4/4] I am extremely careful, almost overly so. I'd be so worried about damaging something that wasn't mine that I would probably handle it with excessive caution....

responses.question: I let people know when there's a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 11. [Rating: 2/4] I usually keep problems to myself. I'm afraid of being seen as a complainer or of making a situation awkward. I only speak up if it's absolutely unavoidable....

turns.message: I've been recording my presentations, but the idea of inviting classmates over makes me a bit uneasy. Maybe I could start by practicing with just one person from my study group.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart adjustment! Starting small with one trusted person builds confidence gradually. You're taking thoughtful steps—keep going at your own pace.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, it feels more manageable this way. I'm hoping this practice will eventually make the larger lecture halls less intimidating.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Small, consistent steps build real confidence. You're already on the right track—soon those lecture halls will feel like just another space where you belong.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I hope so. I've been mapping out the least crowded routes to my front-row seat, which helps a little. It's just hard to shake the feeling that everyone else already has it all figured out.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That seat-mapping strategy is brilliant—using preparation to ease anxiety is a powerful tool. Remember, most people feel just as uncertain; they’re just better at hiding it. You’re doing great by taking control where you can!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks. I just figure if I know exactly where I'm going to sit, I can focus on the lecture instead of feeling exposed. It's one less thing to worry about.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s exactly the right mindset! Controlling what you can—like your seat—frees up mental energy for learning. Keep building on these small wins; they add up to big confidence over time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, that makes sense. I'm already thinking about trying a seat closer to the front in my chemistry lecture next week. Small steps, right?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Absolutely! Moving one row closer is a perfect next step. Celebrate that courage—it’s how growth happens. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks. I just hope it doesn't make me more noticeable to the professor when I'm already stressing about the next exam.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Actually, sitting closer can help you focus better and even make it easier to ask quick questions after class. It turns a stressor into a support tool—you're not just visible, you're engaged!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... I'm just worried about being the first person the professor calls on if I'm right in front. But if it helps me get a better letter of recommendation for that internship, it might be worth it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Professors notice engaged students—and that’s a good thing. Think of it as building a relationship that could lead to strong recommendations. You're turning anxiety into opportunity.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's true, the recommendation letter part is a big motivator. I just need to figure out how to stand out without feeling like I'm bothering them.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great mindset! Try asking one thoughtful question per class or stopping by office hours occasionally. It shows genuine interest without being overbearing. You’re on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point. I could probably manage one question, especially in my smaller seminar. Office hours still feel a bit intimidating, though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small—maybe go with a classmate the first time. Office hours are meant for you, and professors appreciate students who take initiative. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point. I could probably ask someone from my lab group if they're planning to go. I just don't want to ask a question and sound like I wasn't paying attention in the lecture.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect plan! Jot down your question before you go—it shows you’re prepared. And remember, professors expect questions; it means you’re thinking critically. You’ll do great!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea, writing it down will help me stay focused. I just hope I don't freeze up when it's actually time to ask.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It’s totally normal to feel that way! Practice asking your question out loud once or twice beforehand—it builds confidence. You’re more prepared than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that, though I'd probably still run through my internship questions in my head a few more times to make sure they're perfect.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're being thorough, which is great! But remember—perfection isn't the goal; clarity is. Trust that your preparation is enough, and just focus on having a genuine conversation. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Yeah, I know you're right. It's just hard to turn off the part of my brain that wants to have every possible answer prepared."
